title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Introduction
content: The small intestine (small bowel) is a hollow, tubular structure with an average adult length of 22 feet (7 meters), making it the longest portion of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, where the majority of digestion occurs. The small intestine extends from the stomach pylorus to the ileocecal junction and is subdivided into 3 sections: the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. Processing a single meal through the complete length of the small intestine takes up to 5 hours, coordinating with the stomach, gallbladder, and pancreas to cue digestive juices to break down and absorb 95% of food nutrients. The small intestine extracts excess water and sends the remaining food waste to the large intestine to form stool. [1]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Introduction
content: The small intestine is positioned inside the inferior portion of the abdominal cavity, caudal to the stomach, and framed circumferentially by the large intestine. When empty and at rest, the width of the small intestine is about the width of an index finger. This small width gives it the name of the small intestine, not its length. Comparatively, the large intestine is shorter and wider.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Cellular Level
content: The small intestine comprises 4 layers, from innermost to outermost: mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and serosa. Mucosa : The innermost layer of the small intestine, lined by simple columnar epithelium, consists of absorptive cells (enterocytes), goblet cells, and enteroendocrine cells. Enterocytes have approximately 3000 microvilli on their surfaces, increasing the surface area to facilitate effective absorption. [2] Evaginations termed plicae circularis and villi are found in the mucosal layer and increase the surface area for maximal absorption. [3] Invaginations, or crypts, are also found in the mucosal layer and are the site of stem cells; within the crypts, cell renewal and proliferation occur. [4] Submucosa : A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, nerves, and lymphatics. This layer of the small intestine is primarily unspecialized, except in the duodenum, where mucous-secreting Brunner's glands exist.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Cellular Level
content: Muscularis P ropria : Comprises 2 layers of smooth muscle: a thin, outer longitudinal layer and a thick, inner circular layer. The outer longitudinal layer shortens and elates the intestine, while the inner circular layer is responsible for contraction. [2] Between these 2 layers of smooth muscle is the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus of the enteric nervous system (ENS), the neuronal regulator of intestinal movement. Serosa: The outermost layer of the small intestine consisting of epithelium and mesothelium. The serosa covers the jejunum, ileum, and the anterior surface of the duodenum. The posterior aspect of the duodenum is retroperitoneal and not covered by serosa. [2]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Development
content: Development of the small intestine begins at week 3 of gestation and occurs in 3 stages: (1) morphogenesis and cell proliferation, (2) cell differentiation, and (3) functional maturation. [5] Gastrulation, the process of primitive gut tube formation, generates 3 primary germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm. [6] Multiple genes, including SOX9 , GATA4,  and FOXA2 , facilitate the formation of the small intestine. The Hox signaling pathway, involving the interplay between the endoderm and mesoderm, determines the different features of the small intestine.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Development
content: Around week 4 of gestation, the premature midgut forms the yolk sac, which grows more slowly than the developing embryo. Eventually, the edges of the embryonic disc join the midgut, forming the small intestine lumen, while the yolk sac becomes the vitelline duct. By week 5, the midgut has grown to the point of folding onto itself. In week 6, the gut loops herniate through the umbilicus, creating room for the developing bowel, liver, and kidneys. The small bowel returns to the abdomen in weeks 9 to 10. During week 6 herniation, a 90º counterclockwise rotation occurs, which causes the ileum to reach the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. When the bowels return to the abdomen, another counterclockwise rotation of 180º occurs, causing the cecum to sit in the right upper quadrant. [7] Around week 11, the villi and microvilli form, and the small intestinal components are in their final positions. Throughout early development, the epithelium of the small intestine goes through recurrent turnover via stem cells. Originating from neural crest cells, the ENS is completed by week 13 of development. [1]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Development
content: The development of the small bowel is regulated by growth and transcription factors, such as epidermal growth factors (EGF), insulin-like growth factor (IGF), transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β), and hepatocyte growth factor (HGF). Late in gestation, fetal cortisone levels in the blood rise and aid in gut development. [8]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Development
content: While most of the small intestine is part of the midgut, the duodenum is part of both the foregut (anterior gut) and the midgut. The first (superior) part of the duodenum is a part of the foregut. The second (descending) part of the duodenum proximal to the ampulla of Vater is a part of the foregut, while the second (descending) part of the duodenum distal to the ampulla of Vater is a part of the midgut. The third (horizontal) and fourth (ascending) parts of the duodenum are a part of the midgut. The first part of the duodenum and the jejunum and ileum are intraperitoneal organs, and the second to fourth parts of the duodenum are retroperitoneal.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Organ Systems Involved
content: To properly digest nutrients, the small intestine produces enzymes from various organs such as the stomach, gallbladder, pancreas, and salivary glands. Due to the involvement of these organs, malabsorption issues and clinical diagnoses may stem from regions other than the small intestine. For example, pancreatic insufficiency, pernicious anemia, and cystic fibrosis are all diseases involving malabsorption, yet they do not originate in the small intestine.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Function
content: The primary function of the small intestine is to break down food, absorb nutrients, extract water, and move food along the GI tract. The specific functions of each part of the small intestine are detailed below.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Function -- Duodenum - Chemical Digestion
content: The pylorus of the stomach connects to the first part of the small intestine, the duodenum, which receives food from the stomach through the pylorus. Descending and short (10 inches long), the duodenum curves around the pancreas in a "C" shape and receives digestive enzymes from the liver, pancreas, and gallbladder via ducts connecting these organs to the duodenum. In the presence of food, hormone glands in the duodenum lining signal these organs to release enzymes.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Function -- Duodenum - Chemical Digestion
content: The celiac plexus innervates the duodenum, with the sympathetic innervation being the greater and lesser splanchnic nerves and the parasympathetic innervation being the vagus nerve.  Anatomically, the duodenum begins at the duodenal bulb and ends at the Ligament of Treitz, called the duodenojejunal (DJ) flexure. The duodenum is the major site of iron absorption and folate absorption to a lesser extent. [9] The duodenum is divided into 4 distinct parts: Superior The most common site of duodenal ulcers A posterior duodenal ulcer in the superior segment of the duodenum may damage the gastroduodenal artery. Descending Contains the ampulla of Vater and sphincter of Oddi Horizontal The portion of the duodenum where superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome occurs Anteriorly: superior mesenteric vessels Posteriorly aorta Ascending

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Function -- Jejunum - Mechanical Digestion
content: The second part of the small intestine, the jejunum, is located mainly in the abdomen's left upper quadrant (LUQ) and is the folate (B9) absorption site. The jejunum is deep red on endoscopic examination due to numerous blood vessels. The myenteric plexus triggers the intestinal walls of the jejunum to undergo segmentation, churning food and mixing it with digestive enzymes. Peristalsis, the mechanical process by which food moves down the digestive tract, also occurs here.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Function -- Jejunum - Mechanical Digestion
content: The mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum comprises many folds and projections, making the surface area 100 times greater than the skin. 95% of carbohydrates and proteins and 90% of water are absorbed due to this physiology, with the rest absorbed in the large intestine. [10]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Function -- Ileum
content: The ileum is the third and final part of the small intestine. Located mainly in the right lower quadrant (RLQ) of the abdomen, the ileum is the longest section of the small intestine. The ileum is thinner, with more narrow walls and fewer blood vessels. Food spends most of its time in the ileum. Within the ileum, segmentation slows, and peristalsis takes over. The ileocecal valve separates the ileum from the large intestine (colon). Hormones and nerves signal the valve to open and close, allowing food to pass and keeping bacteria out. Special immune cells, Paneth cells, line the ileum to protect against bacteria. [11] The ileum is the site of vitamin B12 and bile salt absorption. The jejunum and ileum are innervated by the superior mesenteric plexus, a continuation of the lower portion of the celiac plexus, with the sympathetic innervation being the greater and lesser splanchnic nerves. Parasympathetic innervation is via the vagus nerve.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Mechanism
content: Carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids are digested and absorbed by the small intestine. Dietary carbohydrates begin as polysaccharides, such as amylose, or disaccharides, such as lactose, sucrose, maltose, or trehalose. Each disaccharide is formed by 2 monosaccharides, such as glucose, fructose, and galactose. For the small bowel enterocytes to absorb carbohydrates, they must be broken down into monosaccharides. [12] The enzyme responsible for carbohydrate digestion is amylase, found in the saliva and pancreas. Alpha-amylase is located in the mouth and begins the digestion of carbohydrates, while pancreatic amylase is primarily responsible for hydrolyzing starches. Along with amylase, the small intestine brush border contains enzymes that digest carbohydrates, including maltase, isomaltase, sucrase, β-galactosidase, and trehalase complex. The monosaccharides are absorbed on the apical membrane via carrier-mediated transporters SGLT1 and GLUT5. Glucose and galactose use SGLT1 (fueled by sodium), and GLUT5 transports fructose. [13]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Mechanism
content: Protein digestion occurs by breaking peptide bonds through hydrolysis by proteolytic enzymes. Proteins are broken down into their primary amino acids. Pepsin is a proteolytic enzyme in the stomach, where protein digestion starts. Chief cells secrete pepsinogen, an inactive precursor of pepsin, which can activate itself. Although pepsin helps digestion in the stomach, it is not completely necessary for protein digestion and must have an environment with a pH of 1 to 3. Pepsin is not found in the small intestine, as the pancreatic fluids cause the duodenum to be alkaline. [14] The pancreas secretes trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase, and carboxypeptidase A and B. These pancreatic proteases are released once the duodenum releases cholecystokinin (CCK) in the presence of proteins. The inactive forms of these pancreatic proteases are released first, and enteropeptidase (also called enterokinase) catalyzes the active forms. [15]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Mechanism
content: When trypsin is activated, it can auto-activate itself to slow digestion. Protein digestion yields free amino acids, dipeptides, tripeptides, and oligopeptides. Dipeptides and tripeptides are transported via Pept-1, which requires a hydrogen ion gradient. Amino acid absorption involves many carrier-mediated active and facilitated transport proteins. [1]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Mechanism
content: Dietary fats exist in triglycerides and are acquired primarily from animal sources. Triglycerides are broken down into 2-monoglycerides and fatty acids. Lipid digestion enzymes exist in several areas superior to the duodenum, including lingual, gastric, and pancreatic lipases. CCK release from the duodenum causes sluggish gastric emptying, allowing more time for lipid digestion by the lingual and gastric lipases. Lipases, termed food-bearing lipases, also exist within foods and can auto-digest themselves. Colipase, lipase, phospholipase A2, and cholesterol ester hydrolase are pancreatic enzymes that break down fats. Bile salts cause the inactivation of lipases. [16]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Mechanism
content: Colipase prevents lipase inactivation. Emulsification is essential in fat digestion as it breaks fat globules into smaller droplets, increasing the surface area for pancreatic lipases. Lipid absorption was initially thought to be a passive process, yet the discovery of fatty acid-binding proteins supports an active course. Fatty acids are relocated to the endoplasmic reticulum of enterocytes and reformed. Free fatty acids are commonly absorbed in the jejunum. [17]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Mechanism
content: The small intestine also absorbs vitamins and minerals. Folate is hydrolyzed, absorbed in the duodenum and jejunum, and transported into the portal circulation. [18] Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is absorbed in the terminal ileum. B12 must bind to the R protein in the stomach. After the B12-R complex reaches the duodenum, the R protein is hydrolyzed, and B12 binds to intrinsic factor (IF), secreted by the gastric parietal cells. The B12-IF complex travels to the terminal ileum and enters the enterocyte via ileal receptors. Vitamins A, D, E, and K are fat-soluble and may be passively absorbed in the small bowel. Approximately 9 liters of water travels to the GI tract daily, and the small intestine absorbs 7 to 8 liters, while the colon absorbs the remaining 1 to 2 liters. Water absorption is thought to occur via osmotic gradients and aquaporins on intestinal membranes. [1]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Related Testing
content: Although thorough history intake can narrow the cause of malabsorption, classic symptoms may not be present, and diseases can mimic each other. Diagnostic testing can include imaging studies, serology, and stimulation tests; however, workup is driven by the clinical presentation. Testing begins with routine labs when considering malabsorption on the differential diagnosis. Labs typically include a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), iron studies, urinalysis, and coagulation panel. Further diagnostic testing for suspected problems with absorption should be utilized based on individual patient presentation. These tests may include a combination of the following: qualitative and quantitative stool fat assessment, abdominal ultrasound, serologic markers for specific diseases such as celiac and Crohn disease, and colonoscopy, upper endoscopy, or sigmoidoscopy when warranted.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Related Testing
content: In some cases, additional imaging such as barium studies, magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP), and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) may be necessary to investigate pancreatic causes of malabsorption. [19] When considering carbohydrate malabsorption, tests such as the lactose tolerance test and the D-xylose test (measuring the capacity of small bowel absorption) are used. [20] Direct stimulation tests may detect pancreatic insufficiency, along with measuring fecal elastase-1. Lastly, the Schilling test is an extensive method to identify a B12 deficiency, which is rarely necessary for the clinical setting.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology
content: As the small bowel is the longest section of the GI tract and is responsible for significant absorption and digestion, numerous conditions can arise if dysfunction exists. These include congenital deformities, growths and obstructions, chronic diseases, and infections. title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO)
content: Mechanical blockage of the small bowel with the highest incidence occurs due to post-surgical adhesions. The second most common etiology of SBO is a strangulated hernia, followed by malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, foreign bodies, volvulus, and stool impaction. [21]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Enteritis
content: Inflammation of the small intestine, commonly caused by radiation exposure or viral/bacterial pathogens (eg, Norovirus , C difficile , E coli ) When the stomach is affected, it is termed gastroenteritis. When the colon is affected, it is termed enterocolitis.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)
content: Erosion of the inner lining of the GI tract due to increased gastric acid secretion Typically, PUD occurs in the stomach and proximal duodenum but may also involve the esophagus, distal duodenum, or jejunum. [22]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
content: Not to be mistaken for irritable bowel disease, IBS, also called spastic colon, is a poorly understood syndrome that results in abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and constipation. Motility disturbances and visceral hypersensitivity characterize IBS. [23]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Intestinal Pseudo-Obstruction
content: Signs and symptoms of bowel obstruction (eg, dilated bowel with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting) without an identified anatomic obstruction. [24]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Celiac Disease
content: Also called gluten-sensitive enteropathy, celiac disease is an autoimmune small intestine disease. The body responds to gluten intake with an uncompensated immune response, leading to small intestine inflammation and damage. [25]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Crohn Disease
content: An autoimmune disease characterized by full-thickness inflammation of the GI tract that may lead to fistulas and strictures. Approximately one-third of Crohn disease patients have involvement of the small bowel, typically within the terminal ileum. [26]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Meckel Diverticulum
content: Incomplete obliteration of the omphalomesenteric duct during embryological development of the GI tract leads to a diverticulum (outpouching) of the small intestine. Typically remembered by the 'rule of 2's'. The condition occurs in 2% of the population, typically in children under 2 years of age, usually located 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, affects males 2x as often as females, and is 2 inches long or less. [27]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Short Bowel Syndrome (SBS)
content: SBS may occur as a genetic defect at birth or following surgical resection of the small bowel. As the small bowel is the site of most nutrient and water absorption, SBS is characterized by an inability to absorb fluids and vital nutrients. [28]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO)
content: SIBO is characterized by an overall increase in bacteria of the small intestine and typically occurs following surgery, when the passage of food and waste slows through the GI tract, leading to optimal conditions for bacterial overgrowth. [29]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) Syndrome
content: The duodenum's third (horizontal) part sits between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. SMA syndrome typically manifests in patients who have undergone substantial weight loss, as the mesenteric fat pad between the duodenum and the vasculature structures becomes smaller, and the duodenum is at an increased risk of compression by these structures. [30]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Duodenal Atresia
content: A congenital defect resulting from the failure to recanalize a portion of the duodenum, leading to complete occlusion or absence of the duodenal lumen. Presents with vomiting in the first 24 to 36 hours of life. Surgical repair via duodenoduodenostomy is necessary. [31]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Necrotizing Enterocolitis
content: Hemorrhagic necrotizing inflammation of the intestinal wall of premature neonates, most commonly occurring in the distal ileum and proximal colon. The causes are not entirely understood; necrotizing enterocolitis is thought to occur due to an underdeveloped immune system. [32]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Intussusception
content: It occurs when the proximal portion of the small bowel telescopes into the distal portion, leading to obstruction and bowel ischemia. [33]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Enterocele (Small Bowel Prolapse)
content: A type of pelvic organ prolapse in which a portion of the small bowel descends into the pelvic cavity, creating a bulge in the vagina. Those most likely to develop an enterocele include multiparous and post-menopausal women. [34]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Pathophysiology -- Carcinoma of the Small Intestine
content: Small bowel cancers comprise < 5% of all GI cancers and include adenocarcinoma, neuroendocrine tumors, lymphoma, GI stromal tumors, leiomyosarcoma, liposarcoma, and metastatic disease. [35]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Clinical Significance
content: As a clinician, it is essential to counsel patients on maintaining proper gut health by moderating alcohol intake and tobacco use and consuming adequate amounts of fiber and water. In addition, patients should be educated on the importance of moderate NSAID use, as the 2 leading causes of ulcers in the stomach and duodenum are NSAIDs and H Pylori. NSAIDs can erode the stomach lining, leading to high stomach acid, which can leak into the duodenum and make it vulnerable to bacterial infections such as H Pylori. [36] Understanding the anatomy of the small bowel is relevant, as swallowed foreign bodies are likely to lodge in the narrowest parts of the intestine, including the pylorus, the duodenojejunal flexure, and the ileocecal junction. [37]

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Clinical Significance
content: Malabsorption disorders can be classified as either global, involving the entire mucosa, or partial, dealing with the malabsorption of specific nutrients. Clinical features of malabsorption are particular to the type of nutrient deficiency, yet weight loss and fatty, greasy stools are classical findings of global malabsorption. Most patients present with nonspecific GI symptoms such as abdominal pain, flatulence, anorexia, and distension. Patients with malabsorption issues may also be asymptomatic. [38] During instances of isolated malabsorption, such as celiac disease, specific manifestations, such as bone thinning or iron deficiency anemia, might be the only signs. [39] Carbohydrate malabsorption can cause milk intolerance and watery diarrhea, while protein malabsorption can lead to muscle atrophy and menstrual irregularities.

title: Physiology, Small Bowel -- Clinical Significance
content: Additionally, folic acid malabsorption and iron deficiency lead to anemia. Vitamin A deficiency may cause night blindness, and vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding disorders. Of note, some causes of malabsorption, such as the malabsorption of fats from celiac disease or pancreatic insufficiency, can lead to the malabsorption of other substances, such as vitamin D, which requires chylomicrons to be absorbed effectively. Based on the clinical implications of malabsorption, it is crucial to recognize that these diseases can diminish quality of life. This topic requires continued research as more pediatric patients are reaching adulthood with diseases such as short-bowel syndrome, cystic fibrosis, and inflammatory bowel disease. [40]
